elements.content: We report herein two multifunctional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) that exhibit excellent mutually inclusive electrical and magnetic properties. Accordingly, two cobalt and nickel based MOFs (Co-MOF, Ni-MOF) were generated using a flexible bispyrazole based ligand and 2-sulphono terephthalic acid. The idea is to generate paramagnetic metal ion based magnetic MOFs, which can also be used to fabricate electrical devices by utilizing the immobilized free sulfonic groups and encapsulated H-bonded water clusters for active charge species generation and transportation. Further support comes from the intriguing structural features of the MOFs that include extensive H-bonded water clusters, free sulfonic acid moiety, or syn-anti bridged carboxylates, which make them highly suitable candidates for generating electrical and magnetic materials. Further complementary support for their candidature comes from the high thermal, chemical, and physical stability of the MOFs. The impedance spectroscopy data and I–V results unequivocally support the suitability of the MOFs for electronic device fabrication showing a befitting conductivity value of 1.80 × 10–4 S/m with an ideality factor of 1.06 for Ni-MOF. Interestingly, the Co-MOF shows a light-dependent behavior with conductivity values of 9.09 × 10–5 S/m (dark) and 6.31 × 10–4 S/m (light) and ideality factors of 0.78 (dark) and 0.92 (light). The MOFs, fitted with a free sulfonic acid moiety and extensive H-bonded water clusters, show high potential for proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) development with corroborating proton conductivity values of 1.95× 10–3 S/cm and 5.80 × 10–4 S/cm for Ni-MOF and Co-MOF, respectively, at 95% relative humidity and 85 °C. Moreover, the interesting structural aspects like syn-anti bridged carboxylates prompt us to explore the magnetic behavior of the MOFs. The Ni-MOF shows some interesting antiferromagnetic behavior. The Co-MOF reveals intriguing single molecule magnet behavior with a U eff value of 34 K and moderate relaxation time of 3.5× 10–8 s.

elements.content: We report herein two multifunctional metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) that exhibit excellent mutually inclusive electrical and magnetic properties. Accordingly, two cobalt and nickel-based MOFs (Co-MOF, Ni-MOF) were generated using a flexible bispyrazole based ligand and 2-sulphono terephthalic acid. The Co-MOF shows excellent magnetic and electrical properties, and Ni-MOF shows good proton conductive behavior due to the presence of a free sulfonic group.

elements.content:
Published as part of a Crystal Growth and Design virtual special issue on Molecular Magnets and Switchable Magnetic Materials

Introduction

Notwithstanding their unprecedented fanfare as the next big thing in the field of alternative energy, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) remain a highly interesting class of multifunctional inorganic polymeric materials. The unique blend of mutually inclusive features of inorganic chemistry, polymer science, and porous materials makes a paradigm shift for MOFs, in terms of exploiting the same benefits of precise and meticulous synthetic fundamentals but diversifying the outlook of commercial or industrial interests with a widening range of applications encompassing catalysis, magnetism, sensing, electrical device fabrications, biomedical utilities. In the early years, the researchers, in pursuit of porous absorbent materials, were more interested in optimizing and improving the physical features of MOFs like pore size, surface area, dimensionality, or topology. Subsequently, the investigations were more focused on the resultant empty space or the surface features of the network and less on what these networks were actually made of, viz., the organic functional groups of the linker and nodal metal ions. Ironically, the fates of traditional inorganic compounds mostly depend on the characteristic features of the comprising metal ions and organic functional groups and their mutual interactions. Coincidently, these two default constituents of MOFs are same as that of typical inorganic complexes, except that for the sake of the polymeric nature the former needs divergent isomers of the typical convergent inorganic ligands. A typical comparative example would be the importance of 2,2′ and 4,4′-bipydine ligands in the inorganic complex and MOF formation, respectively. This clearly hints toward a bigger picture in which traditional properties emanating from the metal–ligand chemical reactivity of a traditional inorganic complex with conventional discrete structure can also be reproduced with their tailor-made polymeric form of MOFs.

of, viz., the organic functional groups of the linker and nodal metal
ions. Ironically, the fates of traditional
inorganic compounds mostly depend on the characteristic features of
the comprising metal ions and organic functional groups and their
mutual interactions. Coincidently, these
two default constituents of MOFs are same as that of typical inorganic
complexes, except that for the sake of the polymeric nature the former
needs divergent isomers of the typical convergent inorganic ligands. A typical comparative example would be the importance
of 2,2′ and 4,4′-bipydine ligands in the inorganic complex
and MOF formation, respectively. This clearly hints

from the metal–ligand chemical reactivity of a traditional

elements.content: One such by-and-large overlooked feature of MOFs is the electrical and magnetic properties and their mutual interplay, which primarily originates from either individual or combined inherent electronic features of metal and ligands. However, a serious bone of contention preventing MOFs from being an important class of electrical-magnetic materials is the overwhelming presence of diamagnetic as well as poor-to-negligible nonconductive carbon-rich organic ligands. While magnetic MOFs, in principle, can be prepared by introducing paramagnetic metal centers, a detrimental low magnetic moment density often makes them less attractive compared to traditional inorganic complexes. However, there is a subtle trade-off between weakened magnetic features owing to diamagnetic chassis and some beneficial additional features associated with the complementary well-defined framework. As for example the magnetic MOFs with a remarkably tunable porous topology can be used as magnetic geolite analogues with potential applications in fields like wastewater treatment, drug delivery, heterogeneous catalysis, or sensing.

elements.content: The idea of using MOFs for electrical utilities has had a tremendous boost in recent years owing to various improvisations that outweigh the nonconductive nature of the framework. Two such widely used approaches are (i) grafting of immobilized functional groups such as sulfonic, phosphonic, carboxylic, pyrazole, imidazole, or histamines as a charge species or proton exchange facilitator; (ii) taking advantages of the porous network of MOFs to entrap of conductive-prone guest molecules like water, protic solvents, redox-active cations/anions or oxoacidic anions. These guest molecules are usually entrapped inside the porous channels with the help of weak hydrogen bonds (strength ca. 5 kcal/mol) and readily undergo dynamic transformations like bond breaking/reforming and molecular reorientation. Such dynamical properties play a pivotal role in facilitating the high mobility of charge species or protons and in turn help to steer up the transport of the charged species, thereby enhancing the electrical conductivity.
elements.clean_text:
The idea
of using MOFs for electrical utilities has had a tremendous
boost in recent years owing to various improvisations that outweigh
the nonconductive nature of the framework. Two such widely used approaches are (i) grafting of immobilized
functional groups such as sulfonic, phosphonic, carboxylic, pyrazole,
imidazole, or histamines as a charge species or proton exchange facilitator;
(ii) taking advantages of the porous network of MOFs to entrap of
conductive-prone guest molecules like water, protic solvents, redox-active
cations/anions or oxoacidic anions. These guest
molecules are usually entrapped inside the porous channels with the
help of weak hydrogen bonds (strength ca. 5 kcal/mol) and readily
undergo dynamic transformations like bond breaking/reforming and molecular
reorientation. Such dynamical properties
play a pivotal role in facilitating the high mobility of charge species
or protons and in turn help to steer up the transport of the charged
species, thereby enhancing the electrical conductivity.

elements.content: Recent studies on electrical properties especially showing proton conductivity highlight the continuous need for generating new MOFs with versatile architectures and add-on features, like grafted polar functional groups. The basic prerequisites for inducing magnetic-electrical properties would be generating paramagnetic metal based MOFs with ligand containing functional groups that can facilitate charge activation as well as boosting the charge mobility, preferably through extended hydrogen bonded network. Our recent studies on MOFs, often containing porous channels filled with extensive hydrogen-bonded protic solvents, based on a flexible bispyrazole-based ligand, methylenebis­(3,5-dimethylpyrazole) (H2MDP) showing interesting magnetic and electrical properties, inspired us to further explore this subject.

elements.content: As such, we report herein the synthesis, structural analysis, and electrical and magnetic properties of two multifunctional MOFs {[Co1.5(STA)­(H2MDP)­(H2O)3]·3H2O} n (Co-MOF) and [Ni2(STA)2(H2MDP)2­(H2O)4] n (Ni-MOF) (where H2STA = 2-sulfono terephthalic acid). We envisioned that employment of H2STA and H2MDP, comprising carboxylate, pyrazole, and sulfonic moieties that are well-known to improve electrical-magnetic features, will be highly beneficial in achieving the thematic targeted properties. A variety of possible bridging modes of carboxylate and ortho-oriented sulfonic moieties of H2STA can be expected to provide favorable magnetic exchange interactions. Individually, pyrazole and sulfonic moieties have a natural tendency to instigate charge species generation that can create a suitable environment to install proton carriers inside the pore and facilitate proton exchange easily, an essential perquisite for conductivity-based electrical device fabrication. Indeed, entrapment of extended hydrogen-bonded water/solvent clusters inside porous channels is the recurring theme of crystal structure analyses. Highly impressive electrical conductivity data obtained for the MOFs are consistent with the notion of inducing charge activation and hydrogen bond led proton transportation by introducing specific functional groups like sulfonic acid. On the other hand, highly encouraging magnetic properties including single molecular magnetic behavior demonstrate their importance as magnetic MOFs.

elements.content: The titular ligand bis­(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl) methane (H2MDP) has been prepared following a reported method. The chemicals were procured from Sigma-Aldrich. FT-IR spectra were collected on a Nicolet MAGNA-IR 750 using KBr pellets. Perkin–Elmer 2400 Series-II CHN analyzer was used for elemental analyses. Conductivity results were obtained using a Keithley Source Meter 2635B. TGA data were recorded on a TA Instruments SDT Q600 maintaining an inert environment using 100 mL min–1 N2 flow. PXRD patterns were recorded using a Rigaku Smartlab X-ray diffractometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section
Materials and General Methods
The titular ligand bis­(3,5-dimethyl-1H-pyrazol-4-yl) methane (H2MDP) has been prepared
following a reported method. The chemicals
were procured from Sigma-Aldrich. FT-IR spectra were collected on
a Nicolet MAGNA-IR 750 using KBr pellets. Perkin–Elmer 2400
Series-II CHN analyzer was used for elemental analyses. Conductivity
results were obtained using a Keithley Source Meter 2635B. TGA data
were recorded on a TA Instruments SDT Q600 maintaining an inert environment
using 100 mL min–1 N2 flow. PXRD patterns
were recorded using a Rigaku Smartlab X-ray diffractometer.

elements.content: One mL methanolic solutions of H2MDP (20.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 1 mL aqueous solution of Co (NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) were mixed with 2 mL of DMF solution of monosodium 2-sulphono terephthalate (0.1 mmol 26.8 mg) in an autoclave. Afterward it was kept in oven for 3 days at 80 °C followed by cooling to RT. Deep red, block-shaped crystals were formed after 3 days with 42% yield (with respect to H2MDP), subsequently washed (using H2O-MeOH) and were air-dried.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Co1.5(STA)­(H2MDP)­(H2O)3]·3H2O}
n
 (Co-MOF)
One mL methanolic solutions of H2MDP
(20.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) and 1 mL aqueous solution of Co (NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) were mixed
with 2 mL of DMF solution of monosodium 2-sulphono terephthalate (0.1
mmol 26.8 mg) in an autoclave. Afterward it was kept in oven for 3
days at 80 °C followed by cooling to RT. Deep red, block-shaped
crystals were formed after 3 days with 42% yield (with respect to
H2MDP), subsequently washed (using H2O-MeOH)
and were air-dried.

X-ray Crystallography

X-ray diffraction intensities for both compounds have been recorded at 100 K on a Bruker D8 VENTURE Microfocus diffractometer equipped with a PHOTON II detector with Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), controlled by the APEX3 (v2017.3-0) software package and processed using SAINT. Raw data were integrated and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects using the Bruker APEX III program suite. The structures were solved by direct methods in SHELXS and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F2 in SHELXL. The crystallographic data are tabulated in Supporting Information, and CIF files are deposited with the CCDC. Deposition numbers are provided in Supporting Information.

elements.content: Two different homogeneous solutions of both the compounds were prepared in DMF medium using ultrasonication after the phase purity was confirmed (see Supporting Information, Figures S3–S4). Then, the solutions were spin coated on the front of two properly cleaned indium tin oxide (ITO) coated glass substrates at 1000 rpm by spin coating each unit in turn. Then, the films were dried in a hot air oven. To form the Schottky diodes (SDs), the substrates were subjected to metallization. Aluminum (Al) metal deposition was performed on the thin films with a vacuum coating unit (HINDHIVAC) under a pressure of 10–6 Torr. Thus, the ITO/synthesized cobalt and nickel-based MOF/Al sandwich structure SDs were formed. The metal thickness was around 1 μm, and the effective area of the diode was 7.065 × 10–6 m2.
elements.clean_text:
Fabrication of ITO/Synthesized Transition Metal-Based MOF/Al-Based
Schottky Barrier Diodes
Two different homogeneous solutions
of both the compounds were prepared in DMF medium using ultrasonication
after the phase purity was confirmed (see Supporting Information, Figures S3–S4). Then, the solutions were
spin coated on the front of two properly cleaned indium tin oxide
(ITO) coated glass substrates at 1000 rpm by spin coating each unit
in turn. Then, the films were dried in a hot air oven. To form the
Schottky diodes (SDs), the substrates were subjected to metallization.
Aluminum (Al) metal deposition was performed on the thin films with
a vacuum coating unit (HINDHIVAC) under a pressure of 10–6 Torr. Thus, the ITO/synthesized cobalt and nickel-based MOF/Al sandwich
structure SDs were formed. The metal thickness was around 1 μm,
and the effective area of the diode was 7.065 × 10–6 m2.

elements.content: In order to form a pellet, 150 mg of the MOFs was sandwiched between two carbon paper sheets pelletized using a hydraulic press under 5 Ton cm–2 pressure for 2 min. It is worth mentioning here that the reason for placing C-papers between the electrodes and the sample is to minimize the contact resistance. Once the pellet was formed, the dimensions of 1 cm diameter and 0.1 cm of thickness were determined. The sandwiched pellet was then kept between two probe electrodes (electrode || sample || electrode), made of stainless steel. For measuring the proton conductivity experiments, an AC-electrochemical impedance spectroscopy tool was used. The spectra were recorded under a 100 mV DC potential and using a frequency range of 1 Hz to 1 MHz. An in-house made humidity chamber was used to regulate the specific temperature and humidity. The data collections were repeated on a CH-analyzer with an 8 h interval. Finally, data were processed using EIS-analyzer software to yield the final conductivity
elements.clean_text:
Solid State Proton Conductivity Experiments
In order
to form a pellet, 150 mg of the MOFs was sandwiched between two carbon
paper sheets pelletized using a hydraulic press under 5 Ton cm–2 pressure for 2 min. It is worth mentioning here that
the reason for placing C-papers between the electrodes and the sample
is to minimize the contact resistance. Once the pellet was formed,
the dimensions of 1 cm diameter and 0.1 cm of thickness were determined.
The sandwiched pellet was then kept between two probe electrodes (electrode
|| sample || electrode), made of stainless steel. For measuring the
proton conductivity experiments, an AC-electrochemical impedance spectroscopy
tool was used. The spectra were recorded under a 100 mV DC potential
and using a frequency range of 1 Hz to 1 MHz. An in-house made humidity
chamber was used to regulate the specific temperature and humidity.
The data collections were repeated on a CH-analyzer with an 8 h interval.
Finally, data were processed using EIS-analyzer software to yield
the final conductivity

elements.content:
The conventional I–V experiments were performed at RT in the voltage range of −1 V to +1 V using a Keithley 2635B to analyze the charge conduction process through the interface ().

Magnetic Data Collection

Using a Quantum Design superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer MPMS-3, the DC susceptibility data of powdered crystalline samples were measured. The M–T data (ZFC, FC) were collected by following the conventional way by varying the temperature range 2–300 K under 1 kOe DC field and M–H data were recorded from the temperature range 2–10 K under a 50 kOe DC field. Using an MPMS-XL magnetometer at an excitation field of 4 Oe, and under DC fields between 0–50 kOe, the AC measurements were collected, while the frequency was swept between 1 and 1500 Hz.

elements.content: Microstructural images of the MOFs were recorded on FESEM using the samples of 5 mg of each MOFs in a 5 mL DMF solution after 6 h sonication at room temperature. A large number of discrete bunches of interconnected flakes of dimensions in the range of 5–10 μm × 3–5 μm were obtained. The EDX spectra and subsequent elemental mapping analysis (using both FEGTEM and FEGSEM data) confirm the presence of all the elements (a–h for Ni and i–p for Co) (Figures S5–S6).
elements.clean_text:
Morphological Studies of the MOFs
Microstructural images
of the MOFs were recorded on FESEM using the samples of 5 mg of each
MOFs in a 5 mL DMF solution after 6 h sonication at room temperature.
A large number of discrete bunches of interconnected flakes of dimensions
in the range of 5–10 μm × 3–5 μm were
obtained. The EDX spectra and subsequent elemental mapping analysis
(using both FEGTEM and FEGSEM data) confirm the presence of all the
elements (a–h
for Ni and i–p for Co) (Figures S5–S6).

elements.content: The sample for electronic device fabrication was prepared using the spin-coating of a DMF solution with the powdered sample of the two MOFs. Considering the fact that DMF has a tendency to change the crystallinity of the sample, it is always prudent to crosscheck any change in phase for the spin-coated films. The retention of the original diffraction pattern for the active layer rules out any change in the crystalline phase.

prepared using

crystalline phase.

elements.content:
Our synthetic protocols were purely motivated by the introduction of functional groups that enhance the hydrogen bonding possibility and boost charge activation as well as charge mobility.

Considering the fact that H2MDP is a neutral ligand, we also used a dicarboxylate molecule as an auxiliary ligand to attain charge neutrality. Out of the two essential ligands, the H2MDP molecule has two 1-H pyrazole moieties which promote hydrogen bonding and henceforth enhance the prospect of fabricating electrical devices. We chose H2STA, with a sulfonic moiety, as the auxiliary linker to further supplement charge activation as well as charge mobility. Two MOFs were prepared in good yield using a generalized solvothermal method using M­(NO3)2·6H2O (M = Co­(II), Ni­(II)) (). Both the compounds were also routinely characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, elemental analysis, mass spectroscopy, PXRD, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion
Synthesis
Our synthetic protocols were purely motivated
by the introduction of functional groups that enhance the hydrogen
bonding possibility and boost charge activation as well as charge
mobility.
Considering the fact that H2MDP is a neutral
ligand, we also used a dicarboxylate molecule as an auxiliary ligand
to attain charge neutrality. Out of the two essential ligands, the
H2MDP molecule has two 1-H pyrazole moieties which promote
hydrogen bonding and henceforth enhance the prospect of fabricating
electrical devices. We chose H2STA, with a sulfonic moiety,
as the auxiliary linker to further supplement charge activation as
well as charge mobility. Two MOFs were prepared in good yield using
a generalized solvothermal method using M­(NO3)2·6H2O (M = Co­(II), Ni­(II)) (). Both the compounds were also routinely
characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy,
elemental analysis, mass spectroscopy, PXRD, and single-crystal X-ray
diffraction analyses.

elements.content: The bent and flexible H2MDP molecule has a natural tendency to form a M2L2 type metallocyclic motif (M = Ni­(II), Co­(II); and L = H2MDP), and the current set of MOFs are no exception. The M2L2 units in both the MOFs show a common trend of joining of juxtaposed metal-STA linear chains to form a grid network.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures
The bent and flexible H2MDP molecule has a natural tendency to form a M2L2 type metallocyclic motif (M = Ni­(II), Co­(II); and L = H2MDP), and the current set of MOFs are no exception. The M2L2 units in both
the MOFs show a common trend of joining of juxtaposed metal-STA linear
chains to form a grid network.

elements.content: The crystal structure of Ni-MOF () lived up to all our expectations showing an interesting two-dimensional herringbone architecture studded with immobilized and noncoordinated sulfonic acids on the infinite nanotubular pores that are occupied by charge-polarized protic solvent molecules. The asymmetric unit (triclinic, P1̅) contains two Ni­(II) atoms, two H2MDP molecules, two STA molecules with free sulfonic groups, and four metal-coordinated water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
The crystal structure of Ni-MOF () lived up to all our expectations showing an interesting two-dimensional
herringbone architecture studded with immobilized and noncoordinated
sulfonic acids on the infinite nanotubular pores that are occupied
by charge-polarized protic solvent molecules. The asymmetric unit
(triclinic, P1̅) contains two Ni­(II) atoms,
two H2MDP molecules, two STA molecules with free sulfonic
groups, and four metal-coordinated water molecules.

elements.content: Crystal structure of Ni-MOF showing (top) the smallest repeating rectangular unit of the network containing four protruding free sulfonic acid groups and (bottom) herringbone network.

elements.content: Both metal centers adopt octahedral geometry and coordinate to two H2MDP molecules, two carboxylates of STA moieties, and two water molecules. The dimonodentate STA moieties are arranged in a linear fashion and coordinate to Ni centers to form a parallel array of infinite chains which are subsequently clipped in every alternate metal center in the form of an M2L2 unit and ultimately generate a herringbone network. The smallest repeating rectangular unit of the network has two M2L2 units as opposite arms, while the remaining two opposite arms consist of four STA molecules with four free sulfonic acid moieties. The pair of sulfonic acids situated diagonally in the smallest rectangle unit have the same orientation, while the opposite pair is facing in exactly the opposite direction. The immobilized free sulfonic moieties protruding in the upper and lower direction from the grid plane lead to the formation of an infinite web of hydrogen bonds with the metal-coordinated as well as lattice water molecules and DMF molecules residing between the offset stacking herringbone grid networks.
elements.clean_text:
Both metal centers adopt octahedral geometry and
coordinate to
two H2MDP molecules, two carboxylates of STA moieties,
and two water molecules. The dimonodentate STA moieties are arranged
in a linear fashion and coordinate to Ni centers to form a parallel
array of infinite chains which are subsequently clipped in every alternate
metal center in the form of an M2L2 unit and
ultimately generate a herringbone network. The smallest repeating
rectangular unit of the network has two M2L2 units as opposite arms, while the remaining two opposite arms consist
of four STA molecules with four free sulfonic acid moieties. The pair
of sulfonic acids situated diagonally in the smallest rectangle unit
have the same orientation, while the opposite pair is facing in exactly
the opposite direction. The immobilized free sulfonic moieties protruding
in the upper and lower direction from the grid plane lead to the formation
of an infinite web of hydrogen bonds with the metal-coordinated as
well as lattice water molecules and DMF molecules residing between
the offset stacking herringbone grid networks.

elements.content: Employment of Co­(II) salt brings a drastic change in the coordination behavior of the STA molecule as the sulfonic moiety now coordinates to the metal in the resultant Co-MOF. The asymmetric unit (triclinic, P1̅) contains one H2MDP molecule, one anionic STA moiety, one full and one-half Co­(II) atoms, and three metal-coordinated and three noncoordinating lattice water molecules (). Two symmetry independent Co­(II) adopt different local coordination environments around the metal center. The carboxylate and ortho-oriented sulfonic moiety coordinate to one hexacoordinated cobalt center in chelating fashion, while the remaining sites are occupied by another carboxylate group, two H2MDP molecules, and a water molecule. On the other hand, the basal positions of the second octahedral cobalt atom are occupied by four water molecules, while the axial positions are occupied by the chelating carboxylates which adopt an interesting syn-anti bridging mode. Topologically, the structure can be envisaged as a stripe pattern running vertically along the crystallographic b axis. Each stripe in the pattern is comprised of rectangular grids of two distinctly different polarities. The M2L2 units form nonpolar stripes which are again flanked on either side by polar stripes made of conjoined grids comprising STA moieties. Interestingly, unlike “empty” nonpolar grids, the polar grid-pockets are filled with water molecules that form extensive hydrogen bonds with the metal-coordinated water molecules as well as sulfonic and carboxylate moieties. The resultant infinite web of hydrogen-bonded networks running along the crystallographic c axis could be considered as the most crucial determinant for proton conductivity, details of which are discussed in the following sections.

elements.content: The above analyses of MOFs reveal some important structural features that are highly relevant for designing two different types of electrical appliances properties: fabrication of diode and proton conductivity. The presence of infinitely hydrogen-bonded H2O-MeOH clusters in Co-MOF makes it a suitable candidate for transportation of electrical charge carriers across the network, an important criterion for both diode and proton conductivity. The same is true for the Ni-MOF, with the encouraging presence of an immobilized and hydrogen-bonded free sulfonic acid moiety. It is imperative to note here that for any meaningful real-life applications, the comprising material should exhibit a certain degree of thermal and chemical stability as well as retention of crystallinity (especially for MOFs). The brief description of the results are as follows:
elements.clean_text:
Electrical Properties of the MOFs
The above analyses
of MOFs reveal some important structural features that are highly
relevant for designing two different types of electrical appliances
properties: fabrication of diode and proton conductivity. The presence
of infinitely hydrogen-bonded H2O-MeOH clusters in Co-MOF makes it a suitable candidate for transportation of
electrical charge carriers across the network, an important criterion
for both diode and proton conductivity. The same is true for the Ni-MOF, with the encouraging presence of an immobilized and
hydrogen-bonded free sulfonic acid moiety. It is imperative to note
here that for any meaningful real-life applications, the comprising
material should exhibit a certain degree of thermal and chemical stability
as well as retention of crystallinity (especially for MOFs). The brief
description of the results are as follows:

elements.content: The TGA of the MOFs confirms their high thermal stability up to 450 °C (Figures S7–S8). The retention of crystallinity in terms of thermal stability up to 150 °C was also confirmed using variable temperature PXRD experiments (Figures S9–S10). Keeping in mind that experiments related to proton conductivity and diode fabrication often involve conditions like high humidity and high temperature, both in powder and high-pressure induced pelletized forms, the physical stability of the MOFs were also checked to evaluate their candidature. A hydraulic press was used to generate 5 Ton cm–2 pressure on the MOFs for 1 h duration. The subsequently PXRD pattern obtained for the pressure-induced sample shows no significant change, confirming the retention of structural framework integrity (Figure S15). In another experiment, MOFs were boiled in water at 100 °C for 3 days to check their chemical stability. The PXRD pattern collected for the air-dried samples of the above retains the same diffraction patterns, thereby confirming their structural integrity.
elements.clean_text:
Stability and Phase Purity Studies
The TGA of the MOFs
confirms their high thermal stability up to 450 °C (Figures S7–S8). The retention of crystallinity
in terms of thermal stability up to 150 °C was also confirmed
using variable temperature PXRD experiments (Figures S9–S10). Keeping in mind that experiments related to
proton conductivity and diode fabrication often involve conditions
like high humidity and high temperature, both in powder and high-pressure
induced pelletized forms, the physical stability of the MOFs were
also checked to evaluate their candidature. A hydraulic press was
used to generate 5 Ton cm–2 pressure on the MOFs
for 1 h duration. The subsequently PXRD pattern obtained for the pressure-induced
sample shows no significant change, confirming the retention of structural
framework integrity (Figure S15). In another
experiment, MOFs were boiled in water at 100 °C for 3 days to
check their chemical stability. The PXRD pattern collected for the
air-dried samples of the above retains the same diffraction patterns,
thereby confirming their structural integrity.

elements.content: Although porosity does not guarantee intrinsic proton conductivity, the presence of empty channels or a cavity can have a profound impact on the conductivity values. This is particularly important when the conductivity is measured under externally applied high humidity conditions or in other words in the presence of water vapor that can easily reside or migrate across the porous channels. Naturally, the current MOFs with distinct pores and infinite channels warrant a detail investigation on their surface area and absorbent ability. Standard N2 gas sorption experiments at 77 K were carried out for the MOFs, for which occurrence of Type-III isotherm (Figures S11 and S12) turns out to be a recurrent theme. Both the MOFs show a common trend of uptaking a moderate to low amount of N2 gas, 30.66 cm3/g for Co-MOF and 28.5 cm3/g for Ni-MOF, at STP. Subsequently calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area data, 11.26 m2/g for Co-MOF and 10.35 m2/g for Ni-MOF, further support their relevance in providing porous channels, thereby enhancing the possibility of improved conductivity by providing the required space to entrap and transport the proton carriers.
elements.clean_text:
Surface Area Determination
Although porosity does not
guarantee intrinsic proton conductivity, the presence of empty channels
or a cavity can have a profound impact on the conductivity values.
This is particularly important when the conductivity is measured under
externally applied high humidity conditions or in other words in the
presence of water vapor that can easily reside or migrate across the
porous channels. Naturally, the current MOFs with distinct pores and
infinite channels warrant a detail investigation on their surface
area and absorbent ability. Standard N2 gas sorption experiments
at 77 K were carried out for the MOFs, for which occurrence of Type-III
isotherm (Figures S11 and S12) turns out
to be a recurrent theme. Both the MOFs show a common trend of uptaking
a moderate to low amount of N2 gas, 30.66 cm3/g for Co-MOF and 28.5 cm3/g for Ni-MOF, at STP. Subsequently calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller
(BET) surface area data, 11.26 m2/g for Co-MOF and 10.35 m2/g for Ni-MOF, further support
their relevance in providing porous channels, thereby enhancing the
possibility of improved conductivity by providing the required space
to entrap and transport the proton carriers.

elements.content: The success of a Schottky barrier diode fabrication often depends on the optical band gap, which can easily be determined from the UV–vis spectra. To prepare the samples, 10 mg of each MOFs was taken in a sample vial with 5 mL of DMF and sonicated for 5 h. Subsequently, a thin film of the MOFs was prepared separately and used for collecting UV–vis (300–800 nm) absorption spectra, which show maxima at approximately 270 nm for Ni-MOF and 272 nm for Co-MOF. The band gap (E g) of the MOFs was determined using the following Tauc formula and by extrapolating the linear region of the plot (αhν)2 vs hν to α = 0 absorption. α h ν = A ( h ν − E g ) n where α - absorption coefficient, E g - band gap, h - Planck’s constant, ν - frequency of light, n - electron transition processes dependent constant (considered as 1 2), and A - constant (for an ideal case taken as 1).

elements.content:
The calculated value of E g turns out to be 3.18 eV for Ni-MOF and 3.49 eV for Co-MOF (Figure S16), which indicate both the MOFs can be considered as wide band gap semiconductors.

Schottky Barrier Diode (SBD) Fabrication

Highly ordered unitary cell-like self-assembled networks showing extensive weak intermolecular interactions among the π-conjugated aromatic rings usually promotes charge transportation through-space, adopting a so-called “hopping” mechanism. These kinds of noncovalent interaction-mediated charge transportations often turned out to be the main driving force of optoelectronic device fabrication. We envisioned that the current MOFs with the substantial presence of pi-conjugated rings in the chassis would drive home the through-space charge transportation, thereby improving the prospect of optoelectronic device fabrication. Further encouragement comes from the calculated optical band gap (3.18 and 3.49 eV), which clearly indicates that the materials are semiconducting in nature. Naturally, it prompted us to explore the electrical and optoelectronic potentials of the MOFs. Accordingly, we have developed an as-synthesized Co-MOF and Ni-MOF based metal (Al)-semiconductor Co-MOF and Ni-MOF (MS) junction thin film device, using our previously published methodology. The I–V experiments have been performed under inert conditions (inside nitrogen-glovebox) using those two fabricated devices in dark and photoirradiation (intensity ≈ 100 mW cm–2) conditions at RT at the corresponding applied bias voltage sequentially within the limit ±1 V to analyze the charge transport behavior.

Highly ordered
unitary cell-like self-assembled networks showing extensive weak intermolecular
interactions among the π-conjugated aromatic rings usually promotes
charge transportation through-space, adopting a so-called “hopping”
mechanism. These kinds of noncovalent interaction-mediated
charge transportations often turned out to be the main driving force
of optoelectronic device fabrication. We envisioned
that the current MOFs with the substantial presence of pi-conjugated
rings in the chassis would drive home the through-space charge transportation,
thereby improving the prospect of optoelectronic device fabrication.
Further encouragement comes from the calculated optical band gap (3.18
and 3.49 eV), which clearly indicates that the materials are semiconducting
in nature. Naturally, it prompted us to explore the electrical and
optoelectronic potentials of the MOFs. Accordingly, we have developed
an as-synthesized Co-MOF and Ni-MOF based
metal (Al)-semiconductor Co-MOF and Ni-MOF (MS) junction thin film device, using our previously published methodology. The I–V experiments
have been performed under inert conditions (inside nitrogen-glovebox)
using those two fabricated devices in dark and photoirradiation (intensity
≈ 100 mW cm–2) conditions at RT at the corresponding
applied bias voltage sequentially within the limit ±1 V to analyze
the charge transport behavior.

elements.content: The current–voltage characteristic of the cobalt-based system has been measured in the dark as well as in photoirradiation conditions (). The measured electrical conductivity for the Co-system in the dark condition turned out to be 9.09 × 10–5 S m–1, which is a typical example of a semiconductor. The conductivity shows a significant enhancement after photoirradiation, and it turns out to be 6.31 × 10–4 S m–1, confirming an optoelectronic phenomenon.

The conductivity shows a significant enhancement after photoirradiation,
and it turns out to be 6.31 × 10–4 S m–1, confirming an optoelectronic phenomenon.

elements.content: In a stark contrast, no such changes were observed for the Ni-based device when data were collected under the dark and irradiation condition. The electrical conductivity of the corresponding Ni-system turns out to be 1.80 × 10–4 S/m that also resembles typical semiconductor behavior.

elements.content: Besides, the illustrative current–voltage features of the Al/cobalt based interface in dark as well as photo illumination conditions () represent a nonlinear rectifying behavior, reminiscent to the Schottky diode (SD). Under the photo illumination condition, the Co-based device exhibits a larger current, which is the significance of photosensitivity. Hence, the photosensitivity of the device has been measured, which has been turned to 1.72.

The thermionic emission (TE) theory was used to analyze the obtained I–V characteristics of Co-based SDs. In this regard, Cheung’s method can be used to deduce the necessary diode parameters.

The further utilization of the TE theory and related mathematical equation for current estimation was done to get more insights into the mechanism. I = I 0 exp ( q V η k T ) [ 1 − exp ( − qV η kT ) ] where I 0 = AA* T 2 exp ( − q ϕ B kT ) ϕ B = kT q ln ( AA* T 2 I 0 ) where I 0 - saturation current, q - electronic charge, k - Boltzmann constant, T - temperature (K), V - forward bias voltage, η - ideality factor, ϕB - effective barrier height at zero bias, A - diode area (7.065 × 10–6 m2), A* - effective Richardson constant (1.20 × 106 A m–2 K–2).

elements.content: One of the most fascinating aspects of the fabricated SD is the observation of attaining a near ideal value of 1 for the ideality factor when illuminated with light. This incident represents the lower recombination of charge carriers at the interface and a more homogeneous environment at the barrier junctions. In other words, the photoirradiation induced optoelectronic effects on the as-synthesized complex-based SD manifests far fewer numbers of recombination because of better barrier homogeneity. On the other hand, the ideality factor of Ni-MOF tends to be very close to unity, primarily due to better Schottky contact of the diode (). In this case also the potential barrier heights for the SDs have been calculated using the y-axis intercept of the H(I) vs. I plot (), whereas the slope represents a second determination of the series resistance. The calculated barrier height Ni based SD was evaluated to be 0.45 eV respectively. Interestingly, the ideality factor of Ni-based SD is 1.06, making it a better one compared to its Co-counterpart.

elements.content: The log I vs log V plot for the forward bias was also used to derive further insights from the interfacial carrier transport phenomena (A). The relevant current conduction mechanism is governed by the power law (I ∝ V m ), where m is the slope of the I vs V curve. As illustrated in B, forward bias comprises two regions. Toward the lower end of the bias (Region-I), SD exhibits Ohmic behavior (with slope ∼ 1) obeying the characteristics I ∝ V rule. On the other hand, Region-II represents the higher end of slope, where the current variation follows I ∝ V 2 expression (A). The value of slope for Region-II turns out to be ca. 2, which is a hallmark of a trap free space charge limited current (SCLC) regime. The SCLC regime is observed when the injected carriers are more than the background carriers, leading to the spread of injected carriers and generating a space charge field. In this region, the currents are controlled by this space charge field and are known as SCLC (Figure S17).. The device performance of the current system was estimated by adopting SCLC theory.

elements.content:
The parameters calculated for the SCLC region suggest that the charge transportation of the SDs are enhanced under illumination conditions (Table S4).

The higher mobility implied a higher transport rate under irradiation, while the number of charge carriers also increased under the same condition. The diode parameters of the synthesized complex-based SD demonstrate superior charge transfer kinetics under an irradiation condition. So, these kinds of materials can pave the way for a very promising future in electrical device application.

elements.content: Grafting of proton carrier acidic functional moieties like sulfonic acid inside the pore wall often are considered as a successful strategy for enhancing proton conductivity and as such form the basis of this study. As illustrated in and , the crystal structures of current MOFs show a starkly contrasting coordinating nature of sulfonic groups and offer an interesting comparative study of their suitability as fuel cell membranes. As discussed above, grafting a free acidic functional group (like sulfonic) inside the network and achieving an infinitely H-bonded network (especially through water cluster formation) remain the two most successful approaches of enhancing proton conductivity. Although we were not successful in achieving both of our structural goals in a single MOF, we did achieve both the goals individually in two MOFs and that form the basis of the following comparative study.
elements.clean_text:
Application of the MOFs as Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells
(PEMFCs)
Grafting of proton carrier acidic functional moieties
like sulfonic acid inside the pore wall often are considered as a
successful strategy for enhancing proton conductivity and as such
form the basis of this study. As illustrated
in  and , the crystal structures of current MOFs show a
starkly contrasting coordinating nature of sulfonic groups and offer
an interesting comparative study of their suitability as fuel cell
membranes. As discussed above, grafting a free acidic functional group
(like sulfonic) inside the network and achieving an infinitely H-bonded
network (especially through water cluster formation) remain the two
most successful approaches of enhancing proton conductivity. Although
we were not successful in achieving both of our structural goals in
a single MOF, we did achieve both the goals individually in two MOFs
and that form the basis of the following comparative study.

elements.content: The Ni-MOF retains the free sulfonic moiety; however it coordinates to metal centers in Co-MOF. Notwithstanding the absence of a free sulfonic moiety, the structural aspects of Co-MOF promise to invoke efficient conductivity with the presence of another alternative and equally important prerequisite: an extensive hydrogen bonded and infinitely propagated water cluster along the crystallographic a axis. Accordingly, a detailed variable temperature and relative humidity dependent proton conductivity study of the MOFs has been carried out using alternating current (ac) impedance spectroscopy.

elements.content: As tabulated in (), the conductivity values at 65% humidity and at 30 °C are 3.94 × 10–7 S/cm for Ni-MOF and 1.69 × 10–7 S/cm for Co-MOF. It is well-known fact that the conductivity values are linearly proportional to temperatures and relative humidity. The mutual influences could be rationalized in terms of external supply of charge carrier protons (from water vapor) and their thermally induced enhanced transportation across the system. Naturally, we carry out conductivity measurements at various temperature and humidity. For a systematic study of their mutual interplay, we kept the sample at a fixed humidity and measure the conductivity values at different temperatures, and then repeat the variable-temperature measurements at different fixed humidity (65%, 80% and 95%). As expected, the conductivity values of both the MOFs increases with increasing the relative humidity (, ). Furthermore, with increasing temperature conductivity show a upward trend while the best values for both the systems are obtained as 1.95 × 10–3 S cm–1 and 5.79 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 95% humidity and 85 °C for Ni-MOF and Co-MOF respectively.

elements.content:
As illustrated in , most of the Nyquist plots exhibit an imperfect arc, which prompts us to consider the intercept at the z′ axis as the resistance of the material for proton conduction.

The resultant resistance values were found to follow a decreasing trend from 1.18 × 103 Ω to 65Ω for Ni-MOF and 2.70 × 104 Ω to 219 Ω for Co-MOF, as the temperature was increased from 303 to 358 K at 95% RH. This indicates the improvement of proton conductivity with an increase in temperature due to the thermal activation of charge carriers or protons.

elements.content: Two most popular mechanisms for proton conductivity are the Grotthuss mechanism or more commonly known as “hopping” mechanism and vehicle mechanism. According to the Grotthuss mechanism, proton conduction takes place in two steps. The first step involves the generation of charge species (H+ or proton) with the formation or cleavage of H-bonds between a hydronium ion and water molecules or other H-bonded liquids present in the system. The second step involves the transportation of the resultant charge species or protons that, as the name suggests, hops from one center to another in an extended hydrogen bonded system. The second possible mechanism or vehicle mechanism indeed needs a proton carrier for charge transportation. The process involves the combination of H+ with the available charge carriers, usually entrapped solvent molecules or species such as water, ammonia, which subsequently transported across the system through diffusion. Interestingly, the mechanism adopted by a system for proton conduction can easily be identified from its value of the activation energy (0.1–0.4 eV earmarked for the hopping mechanism, while greater than 0.4 eV adopts the vehicle mechanism).
elements.clean_text:
Activation Energy and Mechanism
Two most popular mechanisms
for proton conductivity are the Grotthuss mechanism or more commonly
known as “hopping” mechanism and vehicle mechanism.
According to the Grotthuss mechanism, proton conduction takes place
in two steps. The first step involves the generation of charge species
(H+ or proton) with the formation or cleavage of H-bonds
between a hydronium ion and water molecules or other H-bonded liquids
present in the system. The second step involves the transportation
of the resultant charge species or protons that, as the name suggests,
hops from one center to another in an extended hydrogen bonded system.
The second possible mechanism or vehicle mechanism indeed needs a
proton carrier for charge transportation. The process involves the
combination of H+ with the available charge carriers, usually
entrapped solvent molecules or species such as water, ammonia, which
subsequently transported across the system through diffusion. Interestingly,
the mechanism adopted by a system for proton conduction can easily
be identified from its value of the activation energy (0.1–0.4
eV earmarked for the hopping mechanism, while greater than 0.4 eV
adopts the vehicle mechanism).

elements.content: The all-important activation energy for proton conduction can be determined using the following Arrhenius equation: ln ( σ T ) = ln ⁡ A − E a / k B T where A - pre-exponential factor, E a - activation energy, T - temperature, k B - Boltzmann constant, σ - proton conductivity.

elements.content: The linearly fitted data in the temperature range of 303–358 K reveal an estimated activation energy of 0.36 eV for Ni-MOF () and thereby confirms that the proton conduction adopts the Grotthuss mechanism. Interestingly, the calculated activation energy for Co-MOF is 0.62 eV, thereby indicating the vehicle mechanism of proton conduction. The different mechanisms adopted by the MOFs can be rationalized from their respective crystal structures. The presence of a large amount of lattice water molecules, forming extensive H-bonds and more importantly propagating along the length of the distinctly porous channels, naturally favors the vehicle mechanism. The absence of any solvent mediated extensive H-bonded network in Ni-MOF, on the other hand, simply means the absence of vehicles required for the transportation of charge carrier, while further support for the hopping mechanism comes from the complementary ionizing capability of the free sulfonic group present in the system.

elements.content: The above results are in good agreement with our assumption that electrical properties can be imparted and improved through molecular engineering of ligands during synthesis of a MOF. Of particular interest was the syn-anti bridging mode of carboxylate groups that are situated in tandem with the chelating coordination of the carboxylate and ortho-oriented sulfonic moiety in Co-MOF (). From a magnetic point view, such coordination modes are of significant importance. Naturally, we shift our focus toward the second objectives of magnetic properties to fully justify the notion of generating an integrated system showing mutually inclusive electrical and magnetic properties. It is worth mentioning here that crystalline phase purity of the MOFs was verified by powder diffraction patterns before magnetic data collection. The variable temperature direct current (DC) magnetic susceptibility data were collected with the crushed microcrystalline samples in the temperature range between 2 and 300 K, with an applied magnetic field of 0.1 T. The χm T (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility) vs T plots for Co-MOF (a) give the χm T value of 8.67 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K, for three Co-centers, which is much higher than the expected spin-only value of three noninteracting Co­(II) centers is 5.625 cm3 mol–1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is due to the orbital contribution arising from each Co­(II) center. The χm T value decreases with decreasing temperature, and after 100 K it sharply falls; with further cooling, the value decreases smoothly and finally reaches a value of 5.16 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. The behavior closely resembles to the antiferromagnetic interaction between the neighboring metal ions. Using the Curie–Weiss equation (b), data were fitted. From the curve of 1/χm vs T, the Curie–Weiss law 1/χm= (T – θ)/C gives the results for C = 8.77 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = −10.87 K. The negative θ for Co-MOF demonstrates antiferromagnetic interactions between adjacent Co­(II) centers. Similar experimental measurements were carried out for Ni-MOF. The χm T versus T plots for Ni-MOF reveal the χm T value of 6.40 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K, for four Ni­(II) centers which is greater than the theoretical spin only value of four noninteracting Ni centers 4 cm3 mol–1 K (S = 1, g = 2.0); this is also due to antiferromagnetic interactions between four Ni­(II) centers at room temperature (e). With decreasing the temperature, the χm T value initially decreases slightly until it reaches 5.53 cm3 mol–1 K at 15 K. Subsequent cooling of the sample slightly increases the χm T value, and it reaches 5.62 cm3 mol–1 K at 9 K. On further cooling, it falls sharply and finally gives the value of 4.26 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. These types of phenomena indicate the ferromagnetic interactions at low temperature. These data also follow the Curie–Weiss law with C = 12.76 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = −7.91 K (f). The result clearly hints at antiferromagnetic interactions between the adjacent Ni­(II) ions at higher temperature.

elements.content: In between the temperature range of 8–13 K from 0 to 5 T isothermal magnetization (M vs H) for Co-MOF was plotted, from which it was observed that the plot does not saturate even at the highest field of 5 T (c). The maximum magnetic moment value was 21.4 emu/g obtained at 8 K. To examine the anisotropy of the system, the magnetic moment was plotted against H/T for 8–13 K, and this shows that all of the isotherms do not fall on the same master plot, which clearly reveals the existence of anisotropy of Co-MOF (d). Further, if we carefully noticed the geometry around the Co center which is bound with the H2MDP in the structure of the Co-MOF it will be observed that there is distortion in the Oh geometry, which may result in magnetic anisotropy for slow relaxation of magnetization. It sparks interest to look for the possibility of slow magnetic relaxation for the Co-MOF. This prompted us to measure AC susceptibility data to evaluate the SMM potential of the Co-MOF. Ni-MOF, however, did not show any significant peak for SMM.

H2MDP in the structure of the Co-MOF it will
be observed that there is distortion in the Oh geometry,
which may result in magnetic anisotropy for slow relaxation of magnetization.
It sparks interest to look for the possibility of slow magnetic relaxation
for the Co-MOF. This prompted us to measure AC susceptibility
data to evaluate the SMM potential of the Co-MOF. Ni-MOF, however, did not show any significant peak for SMM.

elements.content: The data have been recorded for a temperature range of 2–10 K, while the frequency was varied between 10 and 1500 Hz. AC susceptibility data measured at zero DC field (Figure S13) did not show any major peaks for both the in-phase and out-of-phase susceptibility plots. Maybe this is because of the quantum tunnelling of magnetization (QTM), where emphatic fast relaxation occurs. To overcome the QTM, AC data collection has been carried out under different DC fields at a temperature of 2 K. The most prominent and maximum out-of-phase (χ″) magnetic susceptibility data were observed at 0.5 T. Hence, the data were collected under an optimized DC field of 0.5 T. At 0.5 T, both the in-phase and out-of-phase AC susceptibility measurements show observance of maxima in the temperature dependent χ″ and χ′ plots (a,b). The temperature-dependent maxima help us to conclude the existence of the slow relaxation of magnetization of the Co-MOF.

elements.content: Frequency dependency in-phase (χ M′) and out-of-phase (χ M″) AC susceptibility plots were also examined. The SMM behavior of the sample (c,d) was confirmed by the lack of merging of the plots. ln­(ω) was plotted versus 1/T and fitted using the Arrhenius equation: ln­(ω) = ln­(1/τ0) – (E eff/kT) (), where ω is the frequency, (ω = 1/τ)­τ0 is the relaxation time, and E eff is the energy barrier to estimate the relaxation time and energy barrier of Co-MOF. From the fitting, the energy barrier (E/k) = 34(5) K and the relaxation time (τ0) = 3.5 × 10–8 s. The relaxation time is in the range of an SMM. The spin disorder parameter (ϕ) calculated using the equation ϕ = (ΔT P/T P)/(log υ) (υ denotes the frequency used in AC measurement) for Co-MOF is 0.22 (Figure S14), which is greater than 0.1 and belongs to a normal value for a super-paramagnet (ϕ > 0.1), and hence Co-MOF can be considered as an SMM, ruling out the possibility of a spin glass state (ϕ ≈ 0.01).

elements.content: The impetus of the present investigation was to generate multifunctional MOFs showing mutually inclusive electrical and magnetic properties. Accordingly, we have synthesized cobalt and nickel based MOFs using a pyrazole based ligand and 2-sulphono terephthalic acid. Some of the interesting structural features include the presence of an extensive H-bonded water cluster residing in distinct porous channels and a free sulfonic acid moiety facing toward the cavity, as well as chelating carboxylates which adopt an interesting syn-anti bridging mode. While the first two features can have a strong influence on the electrical properties, the occurrence of the last structure is often found to be instrumental in inducing SMM behavior. Indeed, the Co-MOF reveals significant single molecule magnet behavior with a U eff value of 34 K and a relaxation time of 3.5× 10–8 s. As far as the electrical properties are concerned, both the MOFs can be utilized for Schottky barrier diode formation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
The impetus of the present investigation
was to generate multifunctional
MOFs showing mutually inclusive electrical and magnetic properties.
Accordingly, we have synthesized cobalt and nickel based MOFs using
a pyrazole based ligand and 2-sulphono terephthalic acid. Some of
the interesting structural features include the presence of an extensive
H-bonded water cluster residing in distinct porous channels and a
free sulfonic acid moiety facing toward the cavity, as well as chelating
carboxylates which adopt an interesting syn-anti bridging
mode. While the first two features can have a strong influence on
the electrical properties, the occurrence of the last structure is
often found to be instrumental in inducing SMM behavior. Indeed, the Co-MOF reveals significant single molecule magnet behavior
with a U
eff value of 34 K and a relaxation
time of 3.5× 10–8 s. As far as the electrical
properties are concerned, both the MOFs can be utilized for Schottky
barrier diode formation.

other properties: mutually inclusive electrical and magnetic properties
mutually inclusive electrical and magnetic properties

elements.content: The Co-MOF shows an excellent light-dependent diode with ideality factors of 0.78 (in dark) and 0.92 (in the presence of light), while the corresponding conductivity values are 9.09 × 10–5 S/m (dark) 6.31 × 10–4 S/m (light). Ni-MOF, on the other hand, shows a light-independent ideality factor of 1.06 and a conductivity value of 1.80 × 10–4 S/m when it is used as a Schottky barrier diode. Furthermore, both the MOFs show excellent proton conductivity. The free sulfonic acid moiety present inside the network of Ni-MOF acts as a proton carrier facilitator and shows a high proton conductivity value of 1.95× 10–3 S/cm at 95% relative humidity and 85 °C. The Co-MOF, on the other hand, shows an impressive proton conductivity value of 5.80 × 10–4 S/cm at 95% relative humidity and 85 °C, resulting from an inherent extensive H-bonded water cluster residing inside the porous network. Both the MOFs show remarkable mutually inclusive electrical-magnetic properties which can be used for fabricating magnetic storage memory devices or conductivity-based electrical devices like rectifier, logic gates, and membranes for fuel cells.
